title: What else can be determined for block on disk

content.question: Distance <math alttext="meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(m)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.05" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Speed <math alttext="meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(m/s)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.16" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.16</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Force <math alttext="newtons" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(N)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.050" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.050</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> A block of known mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>M</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> is on a disk that rotates about its center, as shown above. The block travels with the disk and does not slip. The block travels at a constant tangential speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>v</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> when at a distance <math alttext="uppercase R" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>R</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> from the center with a centripetal force of magnitude <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>F</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> exerted on it. The tangential speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>v</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> of the block represents the maximum speed of the block without the block slipping on the disk. Which of the following statements about other quantities that might be determined is correct? Select two answers.

choices.label: The centripetal force exerted on the block at a larger radius can be determined, since <math alttext="F equals, the fraction lowercase m v squared over uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><msup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> can be applied using the given known quantities.

The centripetal acceleration of the block can be determined, since <math alttext="a sub c equals, the fraction v squared over lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> since the block’s tangential speed is known and the radius is known.

The coefficient of friction between the block and the disk can be determined, since friction provides the centripetal force and the equation <math alttext="F equals, mu lowercase m g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>μ</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> can be applied.

The total distance traveled by block can be determined by using <math alttext="delta x equals, x minus x sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> using the known quantities.

content.answer: The centripetal acceleration of the block can be determined, since <math alttext="a sub c equals, the fraction v squared over lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> since the block’s tangential speed is known and the radius is known.
